description: From Middle English visioun, from Anglo-Norman visioun, from Old French vision, from Latin vīsiō (“vision, seeing”), noun of action from the perfect passive participle visus (“that which is seen”), from the verb videō (“I see”) + action noun suffix -iō.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The sense or ability of sight.
(countable) Something seen; an object perceived visually.
examples: […] For to a Viſion ſo apparant, Rumor / Cannot be mute […]

entries.meaning: (countable) Something imaginary one thinks one sees.
examples: He tried drinking from the pool of water, but realized it was only a vision.

entries.meaning: (countable, by extension) Something unreal or imaginary; a creation of fancy.
(countable) An ideal or a goal toward which one aspires.
examples: He worked tirelessly toward his vision of world peace.

entries.meaning: (countable) A religious or mystical experience of a supernatural appearance.
examples: He had a vision of the Virgin Mary.

entries.meaning: (countable) A person or thing of extraordinary beauty.

verbs.description: vision (third-person singular simple present visions, present participle visioning, simple past and past participle visioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To imagine something as if it were to be true.
(transitive) To present as in a vision.
